questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common collateral pathway for venous return in cases of IVC obstruction?

options.label: C
options.text: Superficial veins of the anterior abdominal wall

questions.text: How many Houston's valves are typically present in the human rectum?
Which of the following is not involved in the formation of the Marginal Artery of Drummond?
Examine the image below showing a cross-section of the small intestine. Which part of the small intestine does this section belong to?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Jejunum

Ileum

Walls

Thicker and more vascular

Thinner and less vascular

Lumen

Wider, often found empty

Narrower, often found full

Circular folds/plicae circulares

(valves of Kerckring)

Longer and closely set

Smaller and sparsely set

Villi

More, larger, thicker, and leaf-like

Fewer, shorter, thinner, and finger-like

Aggregated lymph follicles (Peyer's patches)

Small, circular, and few in number, found only in the distal part of the jejunum

Large, oval, more in number, found throughout the ileum, maximum in the distal part

Mesentery

Contains less fat, becomes semitranslucent between the vasa recta, called peritoneal windows

Contains more fat, no peritoneal windows between the vasa recta

Arterial arcades

One or two rows with long vasa recta

Four or five rows with short vasa recta

questions.text: Where is the paraduodenal recess located, and which structure is found in its fold?

options.label: A
options.text: To the right of the duodenum, contains the superior mesenteric artery.

options.label: B
options.text: To the left of the fourth part of the duodenum, contains the inferior mesenteric vein.

options.label: C
options.text: To the left of the fourth part of the duodenum, contains the superior mesenteric vein.

options.label: D
options.text: In front of the pancreas, contains the splenic vein.

questions.correct_answer: B. To the left of the fourth part of the duodenum, contains the inferior mesenteric vein.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the anatomical extent of the attached border of the following structure?

options.label: A
options.text: Duodenojejunal flexure to the ileocecal junction

options.label: B
options.text: Pylorus of the stomach to the transverse colon

options.label: C
options.text: Duodenojejunal flexure to the right iliac fossa

questions.correct_answer: A. Duodenojejunal flexure to the ileocecal junction

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents with increasing abdominal swelling, difficulty swallowing, and hematemesis. On examination, he has a distended abdomen, and upon palpation, his spleen is enlarged. Which anatomical feature is primarily responsible for his hematemesis?

options.label: B
options.text: Left gastric to esophageal vein connections

options.label: C
options.text: Superior to middle rectal vein connections

options.label: D
options.text: Splenic to inferior mesenteric vein connections

questions.correct_answer: B. Left gastric to esophageal vein connections
questions.explanation:
Site of anastomosis

Veins forming portocaval anastomosis

Clinical signs

Lower third of the esophagus

Left gastric vein

↑↓

Esophageal veins draining into azygos vein

Esophageal varices

Umbilicus

Paraumbilical veins

↑↓

Superficial veins of anterior abdominal wall

 

Caput medusae

Mid-anal canal

Superior rectal vein

↑↓

Middle and inferior rectal veins

Hemorrhoids

questions.text: In cases of a strangulated internal hernia into the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen, the surgical approach is often made through the greater omentum as the epiploic foramen cannot be safely widened. Which of the following structures around the epiploic foramen restricts its enlargement during surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Hepatic artery, bile duct, portal vein

options.label: D
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery, cystic duct, portal vein

questions.correct_answer: A. Hepatic artery, bile duct, portal vein

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical relationships is incorrect regarding portal venous circulation?

options.label: A
options.text: The portal vein is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas

options.label: B
options.text: The splenic vein joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein

options.label: C
options.text: The portal vein ends at the porta hepatis

options.label: D
options.text: The portal vein is located posterior to the Inferior vena cava

questions.correct_answer: D. The portal vein is located posterior to the Inferior vena cava
questions.explanation:
Relation

Part

Anteriorly

Posteriorly

Infraduodenal part

Neck of pancreas

Inferior vena cava

Retroduodenal part

First part of duodenum, bile duct, gastroduodenal artery

Inferior vena cava

Supraduodenal part

Hepatic artery, bile duct (free margin of the lesser omentum).

Inferior vena cava

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A CT scan reveals a lesion affecting the distal third of the transverse colon and the descending colon. Which of the following arteries is most likely involved in the blood supply to this region?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Origin

Branches

Organs Supplied

Celiac Trunk

T12 (Thoracic)

Left gastric, common hepatic, splenic

Stomach, liver, pancreas, spleen, duodenum

Superior Mesenteric Artery

L1 (Lumbar)

-

Jejunum, ileum, cecum, colon (ascending, transverse)

Inferior Mesenteric Artery

L3 (Lumbar)

-

Transverse colon (distal), descending colon, sigmoid, rectum, anal canal

questions.text: During abdominal surgery, the surgeon encounters a paired venous structure running vertically along the posterior abdominal wall continuing into the thoracic cavity, just lateral to the vertebral column as shown in the image below. What is this structure most likely?
A surgeon must be careful with the inferior vena cava and its associated vessels during laparoscopic nephrectomy. Which of the following is true about IVC?

options.label: A
options.text: Left gonadal vein drains directly into IVC

options.label: B
options.text: Common iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava at L3 vertebra level

options.label: C
options.text: Three large hepatic veins drain the liver into inferior vena cava

options.label: D
options.text: Right and left 5th lumbar veins drain into IVC

questions.correct_answer: C. Three large hepatic veins drain the liver into inferior vena cava
questions.explanation:
Tributaries of IVC

Key features

Right and left 3rd and 4th lumbar veins

It drains the posterior, lateral, and anterior abdominal walls into IVC.

Right gonadal vein

Left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right suprarenal vein

Left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right inferior phrenic vein

Left inferior phrenic vein drains into the left suprarenal, or left renal vein.

Right and left renal veins

Left renal vein (7.5cm) is three times longer than right renal vein (2.5cm)

Hepatic veins

Three large and many small veins open directly into the anterior surface of the inferior vena cava just before it pierces the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are NOT a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? Superior vesical Obturator Middle rectal Iliolumbar Inferior gluteal
A medical student is reviewing the anatomy of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) and its branches. Which of the following statements about the IMA is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The IMA arises from the abdominal aorta at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

options.label: B
options.text: The IMA supplies the proximal segments of the small intestine.

options.label: C
options.text: The IMA gives rise to the superior rectal artery, which supplies the rectum.

options.label: D
options.text: IMA provides collateral circulation if SMA is stenosed

questions.correct_answer: B. The IMA supplies the proximal segments of the small intestine.
questions.explanation:
Branch

Course & Anastomosis

Supplied Regions

Left Colic Artery

Ascends within left colic mesentery; forms part of the marginal artery of Drummond

Distal transverse colon, descending colon

Sigmoid Arteries

Descend obliquely in sigmoid mesocolon; anastomose with left colic and superior rectal arteries

Distal descending colon, sigmoid colon

Superior Rectal Artery

Crosses left common iliac vessels; descends to rectum, divides into two branches

Rectum, proximal anal canal

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with chronic postprandial abdominal pain and weight loss. Imaging reveals compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. Which of the following best explains the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Branch

Supplies

Inferior pancreaticoduodenal

Head of pancreas, duodenum

Jejunal and Ileal arteries

Jejunum, ileum (via arcades and straight arteries)

Ileocolic artery

Ileum, cecum, appendix (gives rise to cecal & appendicular arteries)

Right colic artery

Ascending colon

Middle colic artery

Transverse colon

Condition

Description

Surgical Importance

Key for procedures like bypass or embolectomy in intestinal ischemia.

Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome

 

Compression of the duodenum by the SMA due to weight loss, causing obstruction.

Collateral Circulation

SMA anastomoses with celiac trunk and inferior mesenteric artery for backup blood flow.

questions.text: A surgical procedure is planned to remove a tumor from the head of the pancreas. Which of the following arterial arcades is primarily responsible for supplying the posterior aspect of the head of the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Artery Type

Origin

Anterior Superior Pancreaticoduodenal

Branches from the gastroduodenal artery

Posterior Superior Pancreaticoduodenal

Branches from the gastroduodenal artery

Anterior Inferior Pancreaticoduodenal

Branches from the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Posterior Inferior Pancreaticoduodenal

Branches from the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Arcade Type

Formed By

Supplies

Anterior Pancreaticoduodenal (Option A ruled out)

Anastomosis of anterior superior and anterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries

Anterior duodenum, head of pancreas, uncinate process

Posterior Pancreaticoduodenal

Anastomosis of posterior superior and posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries

Posterior head of pancreas, adjacent duodenum, distal bile duct

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chronic upper abdominal pain and is diagnosed with compression of the celiac trunk by the median arcuate ligament. Which of the following arteries is not a direct branch of the celiac trunk?
